wikipedia_page.main: Reginald John Rudall (27 September 1885 – 1 January 1955) was a lawyer and politician in Gawler, South Australia. His father, Samuel Bruce Rudall, was member for Barossa 1906–1915.

response: : Barossa independent MHA Dr Herbert Basedow died on 4 June 1933. LCL candidate Reginald Rudall won the resulting by-election on 8 July.

response: : LCL MLC Reginald Rudall died on 1 January 1955. Ross Story was elected to the vacancy on 26 February.

link_mentions.page: Ross Story
response: He was elected to a Midland seat on the Legislative Council in February 1955 to fill a seat made vacant by the death of Reginald Rudall, and held it until July 1975.

link_mentions.page: Reginald John Rudall
Leslie Duncan
response: He died at Hutchison Hospital, Gawler. The burial took place at Willaston General Cemetery, where the pallbearers were the Premier (Thomas Playford IV), the Leader of the Opposition (Mick O'Halloran), the Attorney General (Reginald Rudall), C. R. Hawke, J. F. Power, and K. L. Barnet.

link_mentions.page: List of South Australian Legislative Council by-elections
1933 Barossa state by-election
response: The seat was contested by four candidates: solicitor Reginald Rudall for the governing Liberal and Country League, former MP Thomas Edwards, who listed his occupation as "out of business", for the Parliamentary Labor Party, labourer Leslie McMullin for the Labor Party, and farmer Lindsay Yelland as an independent. All four candidates had contested Barossa at the 1933 election. The by-election was held, as with the 1933 election, in the aftermath of the 1932 Labor split, in which the state Labor Party had split into three separate and competing parties. Edwards had been an incumbent at the time of the split, and had followed the Cabinet into the separate Parliamentary Labor Party when they were expelled over their response to the Great Depression, before his defeat by Basedow in 1933. A rumoured candidate from the third Labor splinter, the Lang Labor Party, did not emerge.

link_mentions.page: Queen's College, North Adelaide
response: Other notable students included Lawrence Bragg, Cecil Hackett, Elton Mayo and his brother Herbert Mayo, Victor Marra Newland, Grenfell Price, Walter Parsons, Reginald Rudall and Arthur Rymill
